instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD_REG: What is PP0V9_SSD_REG? PP0V9_SSD_REG is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD inside newer Macbooks. This must be present for the machineâ€™s SSD to work. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - internal storage not detected - Pristine board
threads.message:
As the title says it, internal storage is not detected.
Both in macOS using another disk or using the data recovery tool which can be plugged to the J9600 connector.

Logicboard is spotless.

I did some diode mode measurement on J9600 and they all compare similarly with a know working board and with the measurements found on Shiny computers' Wiki.
It's a little bit off on some lines but there are no shorts.

<SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_INT_CONN_L</SIGNAL> on the trackpad connector (J4501) however measures .65 instead of .47 which seems quite a big difference.
<SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_INT_L</SIGNAL> is measuring the same resistance to ground and connects directly to the CPU through <CHIP>U4531</CHIP>.

Would could prevent the data recovery tool from accessing the internal drive other than the SSD controller on some NAND chips in your opinion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - internal storage not detected - Pristine board
threads.message:
Did you fix in place the metal plate of J9600, when test the board in normal mode?
Do you get all SSD related voltages?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - internal storage not detected - Pristine board
threads.message:
Yes the lifeboat connector was plugged in.
SSD voltages seem to be present but there are so many that I can't be sure I am not missing one.
1.2, 1.8, cold, hot, etc...

Is there a list of them?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - internal storage not detected - Pristine board
threads.message:
You should check all SSD voltages which can be generated from J9600 power rails.
The reason is that these voltages must be also generated when you connect the recovery tool.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - internal storage not detected - Pristine board
threads.message:
I just checked and I am getting them all.

I took some measurements on the test points next to <CAPACITOR>C9409</CAPACITOR>.
Please let me know if you see any measurement off or if there is anything else I can try before giving up on this one.
What a waste... such a nice board with high specs.
Nothing is getting hot other than the CPU when on (normal temp) so I don't suspect any short.
NANDs and controller are staying 30-37 degrees C so pretty cool.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - internal storage not detected - Pristine board
threads.message:
You should compare with working board.

If all voltages are OK, the should be communication problem between SSD chips...
